etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Thomas Granger (1578–?1627), Church of England clergyman and author. From classical Latin adrogāt-, past participial stem of adrogāre (also arrogāre) arrogate

definitions: To adopt (a person who is not subject to the legal power of another). Also without object: to adopt in this way. Compare "arrogate", "sui juris".
